item.title: Python windows service
item.description:
Create a windows service in python is quite easy.

first, install pywin32 and Microsoft Visual C++ Compiler for Python 2.7

Then, use this boilerplate code to run your service.

import servicemanager
import win32event
import win32service
import win32serviceutil

class PySvc(win32serviceutil.ServiceFramework):
    _svc_name_ = "YourService"
    _svc_display_name_ = "Your Service"
    _svc_description_ = "Your Service"

    def __init__(self, args):
        win32serviceutil.ServiceFramework.__init__(self, args)
        # create an event to listen for stop requests on
        self.hWaitStop = win32event.CreateEvent(None, 0, 0, None)

    def SvcDoRun(self):
        """Run the windows service
        """
        rc = None

        self.main()

        # if the stop event hasn't been fired keep looping
        while rc != win32event.WAIT_OBJECT_0:
            # block for 5 seconds and listen for a stop event
            rc = win32event.WaitForSingleObject(self.hWaitStop, 5000)

    def SvcStop(self):
        """Stop the windows service and stop the scheduler instance
        """
        # tell the SCM we're shutting down
        self.ReportServiceStatus(win32service.SERVICE_STOP_PENDING)

        # fire the stop event
        servicemanager.LogInfoMsg("stop event")
        win32event.SetEvent(self.hWaitStop)

    def main(self):
        # do something here
        pass


if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) == 1:
        servicemanager.Initialize()
        servicemanager.PrepareToHostSingle(PySvc)
        servicemanager.StartServiceCtrlDispatcher()
    else:
        win32serviceutil.HandleCommandLine(PySvc)

Then install the service:

As a user:

python win_service.py --username $pc_name --password $plain_password install

As a background service:

python win_service.py install

Manipulate the service in python

import win32serviceutil

# start the service
win32serviceutil.StartService("service_name")

# stop the service
win32serviceutil.StopService("service_name")
# or in case the stop functionality gets blocked like in this case...
"""Stop the windows service by using sc queryex command, if we use
  win32serviceutil.StoptService(self.service_name) it never gets stopped
  because freezer_scheduler.start() blocks the windows service and
  prevents any new signal to reach the service.
  """
  query = 'sc queryex {0}'.format("service_name")
  out = utils.create_subprocess(query)[0]
  pid = None
  for line in out.split('\n'):
      if 'PID' in line:
          pid = line.split(':')[1].strip()

  command = 'taskkill /f /pid {0}'.format(pid)
  utils.create_subprocess(command)

# status of the service
"""Return running status of Freezer Service
by querying win32serviceutil.QueryServiceStatus()
possible running status:
    1 == stop
    4 == running
"""
if win32serviceutil.QueryServiceStatus("service_name")[1] == 4:
    print("{0} is running normally".format("service_name"))
else:
    print("{0} is *NOT* running".format("service_name"))

item.title: Improving UX in OpenStack's Freezer
item.description:
Pending stuff

  • create an index for log files

Overview

Freezer is a backup and restore tool part of the OpenStack infrastructure which has been part of the big tent since liberty release.

Freezer team is planning to grown this project into a complete disaster recovery solution, but in order to do that a big refactoring needs to happen, which is to create plugin layers for all the components inside freezer, the idea is to be as much flexible and lean as possible but being modular implies having common interfaces between components and for the user as well. This post will cover that, how to make freezer usable for end users.

Components

freezer is composed of several components:

  • freezer-agent
  • freezer-scheduler
  • freezer-api
  • python-freezerclient
  • freezer-web-ui

Architecture

User Experience

  • ideas:
    • job shortcuts
    • job templates (is this the same as shortcuts?)
    • python freezer client should install the agent and scheduler as a dependency
    • freezer-agent should only accept –config argument
    • freezer-scheduler should only accept: start, stop, abort jobs
    • all the interaction should be done by the ui or freezerclient
    • Improve the README for all projects
      • but let’s start with the ui and freezerclient

item.title: Python itertools
item.description:
This is the first post to make cheat sheets of the python standard library

Itertools

import itertools

Chain

To combine iterables

from itertools import chain

print list(chain([1, 2, 3], ['a', 'b', 'c']))
# [1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b', 'c']

izip

To combine elements into tuples

from itertools import izip

print list(izip([1, 2, 3], ['a', 'b', 'c']))
# [(1, 'a'), (2, 'b'), (3, 'c')]

islice

To make slices from datasets

from itertools import islice

for i in islice(range(10), 5):
    print i     
# 0
# 1
# 2
# 3
# 4

tee

To create multiple instances of the same iterable

from itertools import tee

i1, i2, i3 = tee(xrange(10), 3)

imap

To map a function with a list of values

from itertools import imap

print list(imap(lambda x: x * x, xrange(10)))
# [0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81]

count

To count objects when no ending might be possible, we define start and step.

from itertools import count

for number, letter in izip(count(0, 10), ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']):
    print '{0}: {1}'.format(number, letter)     
# 0: a
# 10: b
# 20: c
# 30: d
# 40: e

cycle

To iterate over a sequence over and over until the function is stopped

from itertools import cycle

for number, letter in izip(cycle(range(2)), ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']):
    print '{0}: {1}'.format(number, letter)  
# 0: a
# 1: b
# 0: c
# 1: d
# 0: e

repeat

To create an iterable with items that are repeated either indefinitely or with a limit

from itertools import cycle

for number, letter in izip(cycle(range(2)), ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']):
    print '{0}: {1}'.format(number, letter)  
# 0: a
# 1: b
# 0: c
# 1: d
# 0: e

filter

To create a new iterable using the filter provided

from itertools import ifilter

print list(ifilter(lambda x: x < 10, [1, 4, 6, 7, 11, 34, 66, 100, 1]))
# [1, 4, 6, 7, 1]

groupby

To create a new iterable using the filter provided

from operator import itemgetter
from itertools import groupby

attempts = [
    ('dan', 87),
    ('erik', 95),
    ('jason', 79),
    ('erik', 97),
    ('dan', 100)
]

# Sort the list by name for groupby
attempts.sort(key=itemgetter(0))

# Create a dictionary such that name: scores_list
print {key: sorted(map(itemgetter(1), value)) for key, value in groupby(attempts, key=itemgetter(0))}
# {'dan': [87, 100], 'jason': [79], 'erik': [95, 97]}

item.title: Javascript patterns
item.description:
Module Design Pattern

helps encapsulate code and provide public and private methods

var HTMLChanger = (function () {
    var contents = 'contents'

    var changeHTML = function() {
      var element = document.getElementById('attribute-to-change');
      element.innerHTML = contents;
    }

    return {
      callChangeHTML = function() {
        changeHTML()
        console.log('lol')
      }
    };
})();

HTMLChanger.callChangeHTML()

Revealing Design Pattern

var Exposer = (function() {
  var privateVariable = 10

  var privateMethod = function() {
    console.log('privateMethod')
  }

  var methodToExpose = function () {
    console.log('expose this method')
  }

  return {
    publicMethod = methodToExpose
  };
})();

Exposer.publicMethod()

item.title: Jquery show and hide items
item.description:
Hide and show items according to dropdown selection

<select id="action">
  <option value="backup">Backup</option>
  <option value="restore">Restore</option>
</select>

<input type="text" id="backup_input" name="backup_input" value="backup"/>
<input type="text" id="restore_input" name="restore_input" value="restore"/>

<script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.min.js"></script>

<script type="text/javascript">

$(document).ready(function(){
	$("#action").change(function() {
		if ($("#action").val() == 'backup') {
			$("#restore_input").hide();
		}
		else {
			$("#restore_input").show();
		}
	});

	$("#action").change();
});
</script>
